div1.p: Doesn't this paper look official? It's all I have in my desk at the moment; I go through paper so fast I practically support the business. But just lately that hasn't been true; I have been writing letters to you in my head for a month, and today is my first chance to get one on paper. We are summering five grandchildren this year--well, actually, four and one honorary. Our two from London are here, with a Dutch friend, and one from Washington D.C. is here; one from Washington State arrives tonight, and you would love all the giggling action around here. Also we've had English houseguests--until Thursday of last week--and we have been feeling inundated. But we have thought of you.

As I have just written Hilda, I sent off the copies of reviews as requested, and right away. That's one thing I did get done. Mr. Shir-Cliff wrote me a very nice letter to say they had arrived and were just right for his purpose. I ought to have let you know so that you wouldn't be worried about it, but I've been on a dead run to get the household through the days.

I am about to get the Biography manuscript back to Missouri Press for the second reader; it's being retyped, since in the revision I had to work with three typists and that made two type shifts; they promised to match the type but didn't, and the problem for estimates is greater that way. I would like to have the book published by a commercial house, but at the moment I can't mention it to anyone, because of the agreement one has to sign in submitting to Missouri Press. I had to agree not to submit it anywhere else until we had negotiated. The agreement doens't cover you, though--if you think Simon and Schuster might be interested I don't see anything to prevent your dropping a hint. I think I told you but I'm not sure that Dodd, Mead said they would like to have me do a popularized biography when this is out, to reach a different audience. The salesman asked me about this one, but they don't do critical books. I said I would consider it, but the primary thing is to get this one printed. You haven't seen the revision, but I think you'll like the critical sections better; I took out after the scholars a bit for not getting wildly excited years ago. All the talk about the American epic, and there it was!!!

I still cherish the yen to get a book of letters, as you said I might. It will give me a chance to date some things and build a different kind of picture--or rather, let it emerge. You are a many-sided man, John; people can write for years and years and not say it all. It is so good to see you getting the honor you merit--faces light up when someone mentions you--and it isn't always me. You're known very widely now, and all that uproar you hear is me cheering out in your Oregon precinct.

Much, much, much love; I shall never cease to miss seeing you talking about what new honor is on the books. Take care of yourself in the heat, and I'll write avery soon to tell you the book is in the mail to MU Press.
